name: Berserkjahraun
description: Berserkjahraun is an ancient lava field covering the western slopes of Helgafell mountain on the Snæfellsnes Peninsula, approximately halfway between the towns of Stykkishólmur and Grundarfjörður. This 4,000-year-old volcanic landscape erupted in intermittent phases between 3,600 and 4,000 years ago from four prominent scoria craters of varying sizes arranged in an east-west line from Kerlingarskarð (Ogress Pass). The dark, twisted terrain of solidified basaltic lava stretches across the landscape in dramatic formations, creating an otherworldly environment that appears frozen in time from its volcanic birth. Today, Berserkjahraun forms part of the Snæfellsnes UNESCO Global Geopark, a designation recognizing the area's exceptional geological significance and scientific value. The lava field derives its name from one of Iceland's most famous sagas, the Eyrbyggja Saga, which recounts a dramatic tale of love, betrayal, and superhuman feat. According to the medieval narrative, a farmer brought two berserkers—fierce Norse warriors known for fighting in an uncontrollable, trance-like fury—from Sweden to the Snæfellsnes Peninsula. He later gave the berserkers to his brother Víga-Styr, who lived on the opposite side of the impenetrable lava field. One of the Swedish berserkers fell deeply in love with Víga-Styr's daughter Ásgerður and boldly asked for her hand in marriage.

opening_hours.parking: Multiple designated parking spots along Road 558, free parking
opening_hours.access_road: Road 558 from Route 54, winding gravel road suitable for regular cars (no 4x4 required)
opening_hours.hiking_trails: Multiple trails of varying difficulty across lava field, self-guided exploration
opening_hours.best_season: June to August for best conditions (long daylight, reliable road access)
opening_hours.winter_advisory: Icy roads and unpredictable weather, extra caution necessary
opening_hours.formation_age: 3,600-4,000 years old, erupted from four scoria craters at Kerlingarskarð
opening_hours.unesco_geopark: Part of Snæfellsnes UNESCO Global Geopark
opening_hours.saga_connection: Named from Eyrbyggja Saga, archaeological evidence of two large men found buried
opening_hours.distance_from_reykjavik: Approximately 2 hours drive via Route 1 and Route 54
opening_hours.between_towns: Halfway between Stykkishólmur and Grundarfjörður on Road 558 (6 km from Route 54)
